page.title: 12Coast - Lobster Fishing
page.content: On the shore in both East Wemyss and Buckhaven there are a number of small boats on the beach. The locals use these for lobster fishing during the summer. The traps used to catch shellfish vary considerably in shape and size. The traps or 'creels' as the Scottish ones are called may have wooden, metal or plastic bases with a netting cover. Creels are weighted to keep them on the sea bed and baited to attract the lobsters and crabs which enter through the 'eyes' in the netting. The eyes are funnel shaped sections leading into the centre of the creel. The funnel shae makes it impossible for the lobsters and crabs to retreat once they are in the creel. Creels may be fished singly or in a series of up to 60. Here they are normally fished singly or in a short series as their boats are small.
